Deploying a Twitter bot from RStudio

Last month, I made a Twitter bot using RStudio and Github Actions.
R
Twitter
Github Actions
Author

Jacob Eliason

Published

November 11, 2021

What

  • Last month, I made a Twitter bot using RStudio. Every few hours, the bot posts a satellite image and a Wikipedia reference for a given pair of coordinates from my home state of Utah. The bot is inspired by @mattdrayâ€™s @londonmapbot.

How

  • I started by forking Mattâ€™s repository and following his instructions here.
  • I made the following changes to his workflow:
    • Instead of sampling from the greater London area, I sample from a rectangle that contains Utah state boundaries.
    • I found a .shp file from gis.utah.gov and use that file and the sf package to test if the coordinate pair is inside or outside state boundaries. If necessary, I draw new pairs until I find one within state boundaries.
    • I request larger (1280x1280) images from Mapbox.
    • Wikipedia has a feature that shows all pages within 10 km of a given point (such as your current location). Apparently, Wikipedia pages for any â€œlocation, structure, or geographic feature that is more or less fixed in one placeâ€ have latitude and longitude coordinates encoded. Who knew? Itâ€™s possible, then, to paste any coordinate pair into a URL and see whatâ€™s nearby. I do that, and add RSelenium functions to my script to return the text from the first hit on the resultant page. This text is appended to the body of the tweet as a â€œNearby point of interest.â€
    • I add a hashtag to the body of the tweet to make the account a little more discoverable. The hashtag is randomly selected from a list of a dozen or so that I thought were relevant to the accountâ€™s content.
    • I use @hadleywickhamâ€™s emo package to add emoji to brighten up the final result.

  

Why

  • I wanted to learn more about Github Actions. Itâ€™s a surprisingly powerful feature; I definitely will be experimenting more.
  • Iâ€™ve been feeling like I should focus on live projects. Iâ€™ve done a fair number of personal projects in the last year, but nearly all of them are static and live on my hard drive. This felt like an easy way to get something more dynamic off the ground.
  • Iâ€™m still interested in expanding the project by adding an image classification component. When I first started, I was struck by how many of the satellite images showed completely empty space, and I thought it would be interesting to quantify just how many of them are (say, â€œcontain buildings/roads/farmsâ€ vs â€œdonâ€™t containâ€). I ran out of time and energy for now for this portion, but this kind of satellite data still feels like a good canvas for demonstrating that kind of model. I might come back to it around the holidays when I have a little more time.
  • Twitter is fun, simple as.

Questions

  • My repositoryâ€™s action has started to fail intermittentlyâ€”looking through the run history, it probably only succeeded a third of the time this week. Why? It looks like an issue with the webscraping component (Iâ€™m seeing a lot of â€œHTTP Error 303â€), but I canâ€™t figure out why this would happen at some times and not others.
